Docs.summary: Represents a control that contains multiple items that share the same space on the screen.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl> is useful for minimizing screen space usage while allowing an application to expose a large amount of data. A <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl> consists of multiple <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> objects that share the same screen space. Only one <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl> is visible at a time. When a user selects the tab of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem>, the contents of that <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> become visible and the contents of the other <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> objects are hidden.
<xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl> is an <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl>, which means it can contain a collection of objects of any type (such as string, image, or panel). For more information, see the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl> class.
## Customizing the TabControl Control To apply the same property settings to multiple <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl> controls, use the <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.Style%2A> property. You can modify the default <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate> to give the control a unique appearance. For more information about creating a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate>, see [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/customizing-the-appearance-of-an-existing-control.md). To see the parts and states that are specific to the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl>, see [TabControl Styles and Templates](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/tabcontrol-styles-and-templates.md).
Dependency properties for this control might be set by the control's default style. If a property is set by a default style, the property might change from its default value when the control appears in the application. The default style is determined by which desktop theme is used when the application is running. For more information, see [Default WPF Themes](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=158252).
> [!NOTE] > Setting a visual property will only have an effect if that property is both present in <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl> control's default template and is set by using a . You can find a list of visual properties in the "Changing the Visual Structure of a Control" section in [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/customizing-the-appearance-of-an-existing-control.md).
## Examples The following example creates a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl> and binds the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBlock> in the second <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> to a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBox> in the first <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem>.
[!code-xaml[ControlContentOverviewSnippets#16](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/ControlContentOverviewSnippets/CSharp/Window1.xaml#16)]

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ ContentStringFormat { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.ContentStringFormat : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets a composite string that specifies how to format the contents of the objects if they are displayed as strings.
Docs.value: A composite string that specifies how to format the contents of the objects if they are displayed as strings.

remarks.format:
## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl.ContentStringFormat%2A> can be a predefined, composite, or custom string format. For more information about string formats, see [Formatting Types](~/docs/standard/base-types/formatting-types.md). If you set the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl.ContentTemplate%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl.ContentTemplateSelector%2A> of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl>, the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl.ContentStringFormat%2A> property is ignored.
## Examples The following example binds a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl> to a collection of `Student` objects. The `Student` class has a `Name` property, a collection of `Course` objects, and implements the <xref:System.IFormattable.ToString%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method to return either the `Name` of the student or a string that lists the student's courses. The example uses <xref:System.Windows.Controls.HeaderedContentControl.HeaderStringFormat%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> to put a student's name in the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.HeaderedContentControl.Header%2A> of each <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> (which inherits from <xref:System.Windows.Controls.HeaderedContentControl>), and the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl.ContentStringFormat%2A> to display the course list for each student in the Content of the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem>.
[!code-xaml[ContentStringSnippets#TabControl](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/ContentStringSnippets/CSharp/Window1.xaml#tabcontrol)]
The following example implements the <xref:System.IFormattable.ToString%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method to return either the `Name` of the student or a string that lists the student's courses.
[!code-csharp[ContentStringSnippets#TabControlToString](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/ContentStringSnippets/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#tabcontroltostring)] [!code-vb[ContentStringSnippets#TabControlToString](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/ContentStringSnippets/visualbasic/window1.xaml.vb#tabcontroltostring)]

remarks.format: ## Remarks ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` ``` ## XAML Property Element Usage ## XAML Values *ResourceExtension* One of the following: `StaticResource`, or `DynamicResource`. See [XAML Resources](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/xaml-resources.md). *TemplateResourceKey* The key that identifies the template being requested. The key refers to an existing resource in a . > [!NOTE] > Property element syntax is technically possible, but not recommended. See [Inline Styles and Templates](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/inline-styles-and-templates.md). ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None| ## Examples The following example creates two objects. The called `contentTemplate` is assigned to the of the and the called `tabItemTemplate` is assigned to the of the second . All objects contain the white rectangle defined in `contentTemplate`, except the second , which has a gray rectangle, as defined in `tabItemTemplate`. MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::Windows::Controls::DataTemplateSelector ^ ContentTemplateSelector { System::Windows::Controls::DataTemplateSelector ^ get(); void set(System::Windows::Controls::DataTemplateSelector ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a that provides custom logic for choosing the template that is used to display the content of the control.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Typically, you create a when you have more than one for the same type of objects and you want to supply your own logic to choose a to apply based on the properties of each data object. Note that if you have objects of different types, you can set the property on the . If you do that, then there is no need to create a . Furthermore, if you have objects of the same type but with different properties, you can also consider using a or a data converter. For more information, see [Data Templating Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/data-templating-overview.md). To create a template selector, create a class that inherits from and override the method. After your class is defined, you can assign an instance of the class to the template selector property of your element. If both the and the properties are set, then this property is ignored. ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` ``` ## XAML Property Element Usage ``` ``` ## XAML Values *ResourceExtension* One of the following: `StaticResource`, or `DynamicResource`. See [XAML Resources](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/xaml-resources.md). *DataTemplateSelectorClassKey* The key that identifies the selector implementation being requested. The key refers to a derived class that implements a practical override. For information about how to map your custom class, see [XAML Namespaces and Namespace Mapping for WPF XAML](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/xaml-namespaces-and-namespace-mapping-for-wpf-xaml.md). You can also programmatically add an instance of your class as a resource to a resource dictionary. *MyDataTemplateSelectorImplementation* A class derived from and overrides . For information about how to map your custom class, see [XAML Namespaces and Namespace Mapping for WPF XAML](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/xaml-namespaces-and-namespace-mapping-for-wpf-xaml.md). ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None| ## Examples The following example uses the property to display the content of a differently, depending on the hometown of the selected person. [!code-xaml[TabControlContentTemplateSelector#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/TabControlContentTemplateSelector/CSharp/Window1.xaml#1)] [!code-xaml[TabControlContentTemplateSelector#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/TabControlContentTemplateSelector/CSharp/Window1.xaml#2)] [!code-csharp[TabControlContentTemplateSelector#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/TabControlContentTemplateSelector/CSharp/Data.cs#1)] [!code-csharp[TabControlContentTemplateSelector#3](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/TabControlContentTemplateSelector/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#3)] [!code-vb[TabControlContentTemplateSelector#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/TabControlContentTemplateSelector/VisualBasic/Person.vb#1)] [!code-vb[TabControlContentTemplateSelector#3](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/TabControlContentTemplateSelector/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#3)]

remarks.format: ## Remarks The control raises the <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.IsInitialized%2A> event by calling <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.RaiseEvent%2A>. For more information, see [Routed Events Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/routed-events-overview.md).

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base class' method so that registered delegates receive the event.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnKeyDown(class System.Windows.Input.KeyEventArgs e) cil managed
Protected Overrides Sub OnKeyDown (e As KeyEventArgs)

Docs.summary: Provides class handling for the routed event that occurs when the user presses a key.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This implementation marks the <xref:System.Windows.ContentElement.KeyDown> event as handled by setting the <xref:System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs.Handled%2A> property of the event data to `true` when the user presses CTRL+TAB, CTRL+SHIFT+TAB, HOME, or END to navigate between <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> objects. Otherwise, this implementation does not change the handled state (the <xref:System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs.Handled%2A> property) of the <xref:System.Windows.ContentElement.KeyDown> event data.

block.para: If you override , always call the base implementation in your implementation. Failure to call the base implementation prevents base classes from handling the event with a class handler, which might change the run-time behavior of the final class. You can call the base implementation either before or after your special handling, depending on your requirements.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnSelectionChanged(class System.Windows.Controls.SelectionChangedEventArgs e) cil managed
Protected Overrides Sub OnSelectionChanged (e As SelectionChangedEventArgs)

Docs.summary: Raises the routed event.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl> updates the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl.SelectedContent%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl.SelectedContentTemplate%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl.SelectedContentTemplateSelector%2A> properties to the objects used by the currently selected <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem>.
The control raises the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.Selector.SelectionChanged> event by calling <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.RaiseEvent%2A>. For more information, see [Routed Events Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/routed-events-overview.md).

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base class' method so that registered delegates receive the event.
